root:
Infobox Planet name = Anthe image = [[Image:S2007 S 4 PIA08369.gif|250px]] caption = [[Discovery images]] of Anthe bgcolour = #a0ffa0 discovery = yes discoverer = [http://ciclops.org/team/iss_team.php Cassini Imaging Science Team] discovered = May 30, 2007 orbit_ref = ref name="IAUC"{{cite journal | author=C. Porco and the Cassini Imaging Team| title= ''S/ 2007 S 4''| journal=International Astronomical Union Circulars| date= 2007-07-18| volume= 8857 (subscription required)| pages=| url= http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/08800/08857.html}} epoch = semimajor = 197,700 km eccentricity = 0.001 period = 1.03650 d inclination = 0.1° to Saturn's equator satellite_of = [[Saturn]] physical_characteristics = yes mean_radius = ≈ 1 km mass = 5 e12 [[kilogram|kg]]refassumed density of 1.2 g/cm³ density = unknown surface_grav = unknown rotation = assumed [[synchronous rotation|synchronous]] axial_tilt = unknown albedo = unknown '''Anthe''' (pronEngˈænθiː respellANthee,refThis name is too new to appear in dictionaries, but the [[OED]] has the analogous ''rhodanthe'' {{IPA|/roʊˈdænθiː/}}. or as Greek ''Άνθη)'' is a very small [[natural satellite]] of [[Saturn]] lying between the orbits of [[Mimas (moon)|Mimas]] and [[Enceladus (moon)|Enceladus]]. It is also known as Saturn XLIX; its provisional designation was S/2007 S 4. It is named after one of the [[Alkyonides]]; the name means ''flowery''. It is the 60th confirmed moon of Saturn.ref name=jpl{{cite web |date=2007-07-19 |title=''Saturn Turns 60'' |publisher=JPL (Cassini-Huygens) |author=Agle, D. C. |url=http://saturn.jpl.nasa.gov/news/features/feature20070719.cfm |accessdate=2007-07-19}} It was discovered by the [http://ciclops.org/team/iss_team.php Cassini Imaging Team] in images taken on May 30, 2007.ref name="IAUC" Once the discovery was made, a search of older Cassini images revealed this small satellite in observations from as far back as June 2004. It was first announced on July 18, 2007.ref name="IAUC" Anthe is visibly affected by a perturbing mean longitude [[orbital resonance|resonance]] with the much larger Mimas. This causes its [[osculating orbit]]al elements to vary with an amplitude of about 20 km in semi-major axis on a timescale of about 2 Earth years. The close proximity to the orbits of [[Pallene (moon)|Pallene]] and [[Methone (moon)|Methone]] suggests that these moons may form a dynamical family. ==References== reflist
